content.description: Big hands to a short crumbly section to some OW and chimney with a soft rock finish to a ledge with anchor below a flake.
content.protection:
mostly #3 cams and bigger with a set from .75-2

I forget exactly how long this route is but a single 60m is fine.
content.location: About 50' left of Grenade Launcher and just left of a big tree against the wall.

content.description: Good warm-up for the area. Scramble up on soft(er) rock to the base of the crack. Â Jam or layback the gradually expanding crack. The crux is the slightly overhanging bulge near the top. Anchor is new bolts with chains.
content.protection: Singles of BD  0.3 to #1 with doubles in 0.5 and 0.75
content.location: Immediately to the left of Hip Power, on the right side of the wall

content.description: Fingers corner with a reachy crux.

climbs.name: Locktite
climbs.fa: The Dynamic Duo themselves; Jay Smith and Jim Donini

content.description: This route is great. It's identifiable as a long finger crack that faces south south-west, with an anchor consisting of two Metolious rappel hangers. The climbing is engaging and reminds me of an easier version of another of Jay's routes; Manta Ray. Lots of features and lots of finger crack climbing. The original grade of 11- seemed like a sandbag but stick with that if you feel it's fitting.
content.protection: Lots of finger-sized cams from BD .3 to .5. I also used some small c3s with runners to protect the start. The route is long and I think I remember a 70m rope being necessary.
content.location: This route is left of the two .10+ routes Locked Out and Master Lock. It's located up on a bit of a pedestal, and starts out quite thin and bouldery with speckled tan and varnished rock.

climbs.name: IED
climbs.fa: Nate Sydnor and Joe Stern - FFA Nate Sydnor and Dave Sadoff

content.description:
For those unfamiliar with the term, Staff Sergeant William James specialized in diffusing IEDs (Improvised Explosive Devices) in the Oscar-winning movie "The Hurt Locker." You might need to set one off to send this thing.

This Winter we had a good crew of folks who were motivated to posse up at this wall and get busy with some new routes. This is one of 8 additions we collectively put up in January. Many thanks to all those involved.

The route is amazing, and I feel very fortunate to have stumbled upon it. I think it is comparable to Burl Dog in style, quality and difficulty. I would love for some folks to go repeat it, as I think it is one of the better routes I've found and I think it measures up nicely on the tiny crack test-piece circuit.

The climbing is mostly very thin and the crux is technical lie-backing reminiscent of Burl Dog but just a tad easier I think. I'll let others help level out the grade. There is a good ol' fashioned off-width section after the crux as well that adds to the character, but it has a finger crack barely within reach in the back so big gear is not necessary. One can simply run it out or plug in a finger-sized cam deep in there. Imagine carrying a BD #6 through the crux of Burl Dog and you'll see what I mean about foregoing gear of that size.

Another note; In the crux it would be difficult to stop and place gear, as you're lie-backing for all you're worth and the crack tapers to next to nothing. Therefor I think it should be said that this route could be considered a little PG-13 for Indian Creek when truly giving it hell. If you blow it making the final moves of the crux you're taking a ride onto some small gear. Proceed accordingly. Someone stronger could likely stop and fiddle in a purple or grey c3, but I think it's wiser to just make a run for the tips crack after placing your last sensibly-sized cams.
content.protection: A healthy serving of tiny cams from purple to red c3/green Alien, along with likely three or four pieces in the BD .3 /yellow Alien/.4 range. That's about it. If you are considering going into C1 mode you likely need more than that, but if you belong on this route you should be able to ascertain from the ground what you need. A 60m rope works fine.
content.location: This route is located in a distinct red shield all by itself. It is left of Hurt Locker and right of the two .10+ routes Locked Out and Master Lock. The photos will help with identification.

climbs.name: The Hurt Locker
climbs.fa: The Dynamic Duo themselves; Jay Smith and Jim Donini

content.description: This route is a classic, albeit a short one. It's obvious over by the wide stuff in a black panel of perfect varnish. The climbing consists of splitter and off-set tips and fingers with a hand jam or two up to the anchor.
content.location: Far right side of the cliff

content.description: Hands and fists, to horizontal OW worming and then diving deep into a squeeze with a fist and ow crack behind the pillar.
content.protection: 2 #2 cams (save one for after the horizontal crack) and 2 #4's and 1 each: #1 cam, #5, #6 and #3. Smaller protection can be used as well in small crack behind pillar. The wide gear protects the horizontal.
content.location: This route is on the furthest right side of the power wall above the boulders in the valley. It is to the right of Short Circuit (awesome, new moderate finger crack).

content.description: The route is inside the chimney formed by a huge flake. Starts as a wide hands crack, but quickly expands to offwidth. Features and options keep the route very reasonable for an offwidth
content.protection: BD #4 through #6 just below the anchors,  a few #5s
content.location: Wide chimney hallway a few hundred yards to the left of Dream a Little Bigger Darlin '

content.description: A bouldery start with thin gear finishes over blocks to a stance. Follow the right-facing .5s corner to a slabby fingers splitter in lighter colored rock with a boulder problem finish.
content.protection: grey C3 to #1 camalot with mostly .4s and .5s
content.location: A few feet left of Lock and Load.

content.description:
This route is a solo traverse and can be done in either direction, or even better, go one way, then return! It can be a great traverse to do when it is hot outside as it is all in the shade. This is the

Parkay Squeeze

of Indian Creek.

This is described starting from near

Dream a Little Bigger Darlin'

:

From the chimney entrance to

Hall of Mirrors

, chimney up as high as you feel like! Traverse until you reach

Hall of Mirrors

(1/3 of the way along the route), and go around the corner.The ground drops beneath you here, so don't fall. It is like an easier version of the

Reed's Pinnacle tunnel-through pitch

.

Eventually the chimney squeezes down suddenly from an offset. Chimney upwards until you reach the crescent-shaped gap to slide through. You are now beneath the end of

Hip Power

.

Chimney over to a corner that turns 90 degrees again, and go around it. If the stacked blocks are still around in this corner, DO NOT TOUCH THEM! They are ready to go. Chimney higher to go around them. Exit via the start to

Hip Power

, and reverse from there for more fun.

You can shorten the route by walking the bottom of about half of the chimneys, but why would you do that?!
content.protection: In the wise words of Chuck Pratt: "Technique is Pro"
content.location: This route traverses behind the large detached blocks leaning against Hurt Locker wall. It links Hip Power to Hall of Mirrors in an S-shaped path.

climbs.name: Everybody Hurts
climbs.fa: Nate Sydnor, Herb Crimp and Joe Stern - FFA Nate Sydnor

content.description: This route reminds me of Devin's route Trash Man at Public Service wall. It's short, kind of fierce and hard on the fingers. There's a funny story behind Trash Man's name that you should ask Devin about sometime. Everybody Hurts is sharp, hence the name (REM reference). The stone is pretty good but it's got these funny runnels in the crack that are analogous to features found on limestone.
content.protection: Lots of small and tiny, along with a few medium-sized cams that fit occasionally.
content.location: This route is closer to the left side of the cliff, just past Schulte's route if I remember correctly. It's easily identifiable as a short right-facing corner with obvious anchors 40 ft. up on top of the pillar.

climbs.name: Enemy Invasion
climbs.fa: The legendary Dave Sadoff and his band of Moabites

content.description:
I saw this last year and wanted to gift it to my good friend Dave who is a master at going ground up on face climbs, drill hanging straight from the harness and all. The way I recall it, Dave (who is seven feet tall and kills men by the hundreds, vis a vis William Wallace) led this thing drilling from stances and never clipping in direct or using hooks. He took some great whips along the way, or did he? I can't remember but it was awesome. It was a great display of sensible craftsmanship by a great guy who has quietly contributed much to the Moab climbing scene. We even got to see a great trundle from the anchor ledge to wrap up the full experience.

The route is on great stone and is likely a candidate for the best (only?) easy-ish bolted route in The Creek.
content.location: Down and right of the .10+ routes Locked Out and Master Lock, on an obvious beautiful pillar.

content.description: A beautiful, clean and consistent squeeze chimney. A 5.10 for some, a 5.7 for others, or just plain harrd! It depends on your body proportions. It starts around 9-10" in width and quickly widens to about 14" for most of the rest. 3/4 up it constricts to 12", and does so again at the top, but you can scootch closer to the outside to pass around these.
content.protection: #4 Big Bros, #8 C4s, #12 Valley Giants. Take your pick! It is also a reasonable solo.
content.location: This is the farthest right left-facing dihedral in the area with an unmistakable chimney.
